column2: _Do not count your chickens before they are hatched._

column2: THE WOLF AND THE SHEPHERD
column3: THE WOLF AND THE SHEPHERD

column2: A Wolf, lurking near the Shepherd's hut, saw the Shepherd and his family feasting on a roasted lamb.

column2: _Men often condemn others for what they see no wrong in doing themselves._

column2: THE GOATHERD AND THE GOAT
column3: THE GOATHERD AND THE GOAT

column2: A Goat strayed away from the flock, tempted by a patch of clover. The Goatherd tried to call it back, but in vain.
column3: A Goat strayed away from the flock, tempted by a patch of clover. The Goatherd tried to call it back, but in vain.

column2: It would not obey him.
column3: It would not obey him.

column2: Then he picked up a stone and threw it, breaking the Goat's horn.
column3: Then he picked up a stone and threw it, breaking the Goat's horn.

column2: The Goatherd was frightened.
column3: The Goatherd was frightened.

column2: Do not tell the master, he begged the Goat.
column3: Do not tell the master, he begged the Goat.

column2: No, said the Goat, "that broken horn can speak for itself!"
column3: No, said the Goat, "that broken horn can speak for itself!"

column2: _Wicked deeds will not stay hid._
column3: underscore Wicked deeds will not stay hid.underscore

column2: THE MISER
column3: THE MISER

column2: A Miser had buried his gold in a secret place in his garden. Every day he went to the spot, dug up the treasure and counted it piece by piece to make sure it was all there.
column3: A Miser had buried his gold in a secret place in his garden. Every day he went to the spot, dug up the treasure and counted it piece by piece to make sure it was all there.

column2: He made so many trips that a Thief, who had been observing him, guessed what it was the Miser had hidden, and one night quietly dug up the treasure and made off with it.
column3: He made so many trips that a Thief, who had been observing him, guessed what it was the Miser had hidden, and one night quietly dug up the treasure and made off with it.

column2: When the Miser discovered his loss, he was overcome with grief and despair.
column3: When the Miser discovered his loss, he was overcome with grief and despair.

column2: He groaned and cried and tore his hair.

column2: A passerby heard his cries and asked what had happened.

column2: My gold!	My gold!

column2: O my gold!" cried the Miser, wildly, "someone has robbed me!"

column2: _A possession is worth no more than the use we make of it._

column2: THE WOLF AND THE HOUSE DOG
column3: THE WOLF AND THE HOUSE DOG

column2: There was once a Wolf who got very little to eat because the Dogs of the village were so wide awake and watchful.
column3: There was once a Wolf who got very little to eat because the Dogs of the village were so wide awake and watchful.

column2: He was really nothing but skin and bones, and it made him very downhearted to think of it.
column3: He was really nothing but skin and bones, and it made him very downhearted to think of it.

column2: One night this Wolf happened to fall in with a fine fat House Dog who had wandered a little too far from home.
column3: One night this Wolf happened to fall in with a fine fat House Dog who had wandered a little too far from home.

column2: The Wolf would gladly have eaten him then and there, but the House Dog looked strong enough to leave his marks should he try it.
column3: The Wolf would gladly have eaten him then and there, but the House Dog looked strong enough to leave his marks should he try it.

column2: So the Wolf spoke very humbly to the Dog, complimenting him on his fine appearance.
column3: So the Wolf spoke very humbly to the Dog, complimenting him on his fine appearance.

column2: You can be as well-fed as I am if you want to, replied the Dog. "Leave the woods; there you live miserably.
column3: You can be as well fed as I am if you want to, replied the Dog. "Leave the woods; there you live miserably.

column2: Why, you have to fight hard for every bite you get.
column3: Why, you have to fight hard for every bite you get.

column2: Follow my example and you will get along beautifully."
column3: Follow my example and you will get along beautifully."

column2: What must I do? asked the Wolf.
column3: What must I do? asked the Wolf.

column2: Hardly anything, answered the House Dog.
column3: Hardly anything, answered the House Dog.

column2: Chase people who carry canes, bark at beggars, and fawn on the people of the house.	Chase people who carry canes, bark at beggars, and fawn on the people of the house.
column3: true

column2: In return you will get tidbits of every kind, chicken bones, choice bits of meat, sugar, cake, and much more beside, not to speak of kind words and caresses."
column3: In return you will get tidbits of every kind, chicken bones, choice bits of meat, sugar, cake, and much more beside, not to speak of kind words and caresses."

column2: The Wolf had such a beautiful vision of his coming happiness that he almost wept.
column3: The Wolf had such a beautiful vision of his coming happiness that he almost wept.

column2: But just then he noticed that the hair on the Dog's neck was worn and the skin was chafed.
column3: But just then he noticed that the hair on the Dog's neck was worn and the skin was chafed.

column2: What is that on your neck?
column3: What is that on your neck?

column2: Nothing at all, replied the Dog.
column3: Nothing at all, replied the Dog.

column2: What! nothing!
column3: What! nothing!

column2: Oh, just a trifle!
column3: Oh, just a trifle!

column2: But please tell me.
column3: But please tell me.

column2: Perhaps you see the mark of the collar to which my chain is fastened.
column3: Perhaps you see the mark of the collar to which my chain is fastened.

column2: What!	What!

column2: A chain!" cried the Wolf.
column3: A chain!" cried the Wolf.

column2: Don't you go wherever you please?
column3: Don't you go wherever you please?

column2: Not always!	Not always!
column3: true

column2: But what's the difference?" replied the Dog.
column3: But what's the difference?" replied the Dog.

column2: All the difference in the world!	All the difference in the world!

column2: THE FOX AND THE HEDGEHOG
column3: THE FOX AND THE HEDGEHOG

column2: A Fox, swimming across a river, was barely able to reach the bank, where he lay bruised and exhausted from his struggle with the swift current.
column3: A Fox, swimming across a river, was barely able to reach the bank, where he lay bruised and exhausted from his struggle with the swift current.

column2: Soon a swarm of blood-sucking flies settled on him; but he lay quietly, still too weak to run away from them.
column3: Soon a swarm of blood sucking flies settled on him; but he lay quietly, still too weak to run away from them.
